text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm with mongolian pork chops this is
the signature dish at one of my favorite
napa valley restaurants mustards Grill
and I'll give you lots of background
info on the blog of course but for now
I'm just going to show you how to make
it and by the way I'm not sure how
authentic this is I haven't been to
Mongolia and ages and I think the last
time I was there I brown bagged it I
don't know if this is really Mongolian
but that's what chef Cindy calls it at
mustards Grill so that's what we're
going to call it and it starts with a
very simple marinade so into a bowl I'm
going to put some hoisin sauce I'm going
to add some crushed garlic and some
crushed ginger and then some hot sauce I
know what mustards they used Tabasco I'm
using sriracha we're also going to put
in a splash of sesame oil some soy sauce
and then an array of vinegars I'm going
to go with red wine vinegar rice vinegar
and sherry vinegar all right so after
the sour we need some sweet I'm going to
add some white sugar
alright I'm also going to put some
pepper in here we're going to use white
pepper and black pepper and white pepper
has a very interesting type of heat that
you don't get from red and black peppers
all right so we're gonna take a whisk
we're gonna whisk that thoroughly and
the marinade is done we're just going to
set that aside and get our pork chops
ready which are these glorious bone-in
extra thick cut pork chops who talked to
a real butcher with one of those
handlebar mustaches and get some
beautiful thick pork chops when you have
those gorgeous chops I want you to put
them in a plastic bag and then listen
very carefully you're just going to pour
over about half the marinade maybe a
little more than half let's say 60%
that's what we're going to use to
marinate the pork chops with the rest
we're going to use as a glaze as it
grills so just reserved about 40% of the
marinade you're going to have plenty and
set that aside of course you're going to
seal up the bag nice and tight and
you're going to refrigerate for a
minimum of 3 or 4 hours I think 6 to 8
hours is optimum and yes you can leave
this overnight all right and while
that's marinating we're going to make a
really unique mustard sauce that gets
served alongside this just like it
mustards Grill so in a heat proof
stainless steel bowl I'm going to add
some red wine vinegar and some dry
mustard now you can use that really hot
Chinese mustard I'm using the stuff in
the yellow can the Colemans double
string but pretty much any hot mustard
powder will work to that we're gonna add
one egg yolk and some sugar and I know
this looks like a bizarre combination
but trust me it really works
so give that a good mix with your whisk
we're going to head over to the stove
and over low heat I'm going to whisk
that continuously over the flame until
it gets hot and slightly thickened now
one egg yolk and that much liquid it's
not going to get super thick all you're
waiting for is to the mixture gets hot
you may see a very faint wisp of steam
really all we're doing here is cooking
the egg yolk once it looks like that
we're going to take it off the heat and
then I'm going to season my knob a
little differently than the official
recipe but I'm going to add a little bit
of cayenne a little bit of Dijon mustard
and then I like to add just a little
touch of turmeric now I'm not a big
tumeric fan but I do like what it does
to the color of the sauce and just that
small amount gives it a nice little
background note and then last but not
least this is finished with creme
fraiche which is basically sour cream
and you can use sour cream but if you
can get creme fraiche or you can make
your own we have a video for that that
works even better of course something
like this you're going to taste and
adjust the seasoning but keep in mind
this is not necessarily supposed to
taste great on your fingertip this is
supposed to taste great on that grilled
marinated pork okay once you're happy
with that just refrigerate till needed
and it's on to the chops which at this
point have been marinating for eight
hours so after I remove these from the
marinade and wipe off any excess I am
going to lightly seasoned them and then
you're free to cook these any way you
want but what is traditional and how
they do it at mustards they grill it
over charcoal you just can't use direct
heat okay so I'm only using high heat
here to sear the outside you get some
nice black grill marks and then I'm
pushing the coals away from the center
alright
the grill still hot around the pork but
not underneath if you have flame
underneath the pork that marinade that
glaze will simply catch on fire and you
will be staring at what looks like two
pieces of black charcoal okay it might
be delicious on the inside but the
outside is going to not look good so I'm
going to have mine over indirect medium
heat I did close the cover in between
basting is here to keep the heat down
even a little more and I'll just keep
brushing that reserved marinade on both
sides until you've built up an amazing
thick glossy glaze alright everybody
loves glossy glazes who doesn't love
glossy glazes nobody and though
took me after I seared gave them the
grill marks on high heat those took me
about 25 minutes over a sort of indirect
medium heat to finish I was shooting for
an internal temperature of 140 which is
just how I like mine or do it your way
you're the boss of your dry overcooked
meat but I go for 140 and at that point
it was perfectly done and I was ready to
enjoy this amazing pork chop experience
so I pulled those off the grill of
course I let it rest a few minutes and
there you go Mongolian pork chops are
traditionally served with mashed
potatoes and braised cabbage of course
I'll show you that sometime and we're
going to cut into this and it is just
spectacular that marinade really
produces a juicy flavorful meat just the
right balance of tangy salty sweet look
at that look at how juicy that is and
then he got that mustard sauce that
little bit of richness from the butter
fat from the creme fraiche the Tang eNOS
from the vinegar balanced by the sugar
and everything elevated by that sharp
nasally heat from the mustard just a
great great combination anyway Thank You
Cindy paulsen Thank You mustards Grill
for the inspiration and Thank You
Mongolia for being there and having this
named after your country anyway I hope
you give that a try
head over to food wishes calm for all
the ingredient amounts and weight more
information as usual and as always enjoy
you
